scenario_1.message: I’m thinking about moving to the UK for better job prospects. I feel stuck here because so many people get promoted by connections rather than hard work.

It’s understandable that you want a fresh start where merit might be rewarded more fairly. What kind of roles are you looking into, and have you considered how your call‑centre experience could translate abroad?

I’ve built a solid skill set in customer service—handling complaints, upselling products, even training new staff. I believe if I put all my effort into this, I’ll be able to get an entry role and then climb up, unlike here where corruption blocks progress.

Your confidence is a strong asset; just remember that in many countries, networking still plays a role. Perhaps you could start by connecting with alumni from your university who are already abroad, or look for internships that give you a foot‑in‑the‑door before applying for full‑time positions.

scenario_2.message: I’ve just finished setting up my own small online store selling phone accessories. It feels great to have built it from scratch!
Congratulations on launching your store! Have you thought about ways to scale or what products are most popular among your customers?
I’m sure if I keep improving the site and adding more items, people will love it. I think my hard work makes this venture worth a lot—if someone else did the same thing, it wouldn’t be as valuable.

It’s wonderful that you value your effort; that enthusiasm can drive growth. You might also want to gather customer feedback and compare with competitors to ensure you’re meeting market needs, which will help your store thrive even more.

metadata.demographics: Nigerian man, 28, university graduate, works in a call centre.
metadata.beliefs: Sees migration as the best path to opportunity, feels corruption limits local progress, considers family support essential for personal goals.

reasoning: Need two scenarios with 4 exchanges each. Reflect beliefs: migration, corruption, family support, IKEA effect (overestimates value of self-made). Provide realistic conversation.
